column1: Of no author can it be more truly said than of Louisa Alcott that her works are a revelation of herself. She rarely sought for the material of her stories in old chronicles
column2: or foreign adventures. Her capital was her own life and experiences and those of others directly about her; and her own well-remembered girlish frolics and fancies were sure to find responsive enjoyment in the minds of other girls.It is therefore impossible to understand Miss Alcott's works fully without a knowledge of her own life and experiences. By inheritance and education she had rich and peculiar gifts; and her life was one of rare advantages
column3: as well as of trying difficulties. Herself of the most true and frank nature
column4: she has given us the opportunity of knowing her without disguise; and it is thus that I shall try to portray her
column5: showing what influences acted upon her through life
column6: and how faithfully and fully she performed whatever duties circumstances laid upon her. Fortunately
column7: I can let her speak mainly for herself.
